title: 107_s1515
content: Enhanced security measures for aircraft. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration is required to implement a security screening program for larger aircraft with a maximum certified takeoff weight of over 12,500 pounds within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The program can be waived for certain aircraft if the Administrator deems it necessary. The Administrator can waive the security screening program for certain aircraft if deemed safe, with approval from the Secretary of Transportation and notification to Congress. The program includes searching aircraft before takeoff and screening crew members and passengers. The Administrator will implement a security program for smaller aircraft with a maximum weight of 12,500 pounds or less within one year of the Act's enactment. The program includes screening all crew members, passengers, and other individuals boarding covered aircraft, as well as their belongings, before boarding. Procedures for searches and screenings must be developed by the Administrator and approved by the Secretary before implementation. The security program for smaller aircraft under the Act includes screening crew members, passengers, and individuals with access to covered aircraft. The Secretary must submit a report on the program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, no person or entity can sell, lease, or charter aircraft to aliens without background checks. No aircraft can be sold, leased, or chartered to an alien in the United States without a background investigation certified by the Attorney General. The investigation includes checking for criminal history and immigration status. In the United States, aircraft sales, leases, or charters to aliens require a background investigation certified by the Attorney General to assess national security risks. The prohibition expires upon implementation of specific programs based on aircraft weight categories. The term "alien" is defined in accordance with the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act defines the term "alien" and requires background investigations for aircraft sales, leases, or charters to aliens in the United States. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.
